nodes.name: Unbounded decision error in AI systems
aliases: decision error without bounds in AI agents
nodes.description: AI systems that lack formal guarantees on the quality of their action choices may make harmful or catastrophic decisions, posing a primary alignment risk.
nodes.node_rationale: Highlighted in the post as the key safety-relevant quantity; decision error is harder to bound than predictive error. (Main body, bullet 2)

nodes.name: Absent decision-error guarantees in standard Bayesian and logical induction frameworks
aliases: lack of decision bounds in current epistemic theories
nodes.description: Existing epistemic approaches (Bayesian decision theory, logical induction) can bound predictive loss but struggle to bound the quality of downstream decisions in embedded agents.
nodes.node_rationale: Explicitly contrasted with infrabayesianism’s advantages. (Main body, bullet 2)

nodes.name: Infrabayesianism supplies realizable epistemics with decision-error bounds
nodes.description: The framework solves the realizability problem for embedded agents and yields systematic techniques to bound decision error, directly relevant to safety proofs.
nodes.node_rationale: Central positive claim about InfraBayes. (Main body, bullets 1 & 2)

nodes.name: Design AI agents using infrabayesian decision principles
aliases: apply infrabayesian decision theory in agent design
nodes.description: Using the infrabayesian update and decision rules as the core of an AI’s reasoning promises formal safety properties.
nodes.node_rationale: Natural design step if InfraBayes solves the identified theoretical gaps. (Implied by bullet 2)

nodes.name: Embed infrabayesian belief update rules into reinforcement learning algorithms
nodes.description: Concrete mechanism: represent the agent’s epistemic state as an infradistribution and apply the corresponding update/decision rules during learning and acting.
nodes.node_rationale: Necessary step to realise the design rationale in practice. (Implied technical mechanism)

nodes.name: Theoretical proofs in infrabayesian sequence showing decision-error bounds
nodes.description: The published sequence contains mathematical proofs that infradistributions yield learning-theoretic guarantees relevant for bounding decision error.
nodes.node_rationale: Only formal evidence cited in the post; supports the implementation mechanism. (Link to sequence provided)

nodes.name: Incorporate infrabayesian decision framework at model design stage
nodes.description: When specifying a new AI system, choose an architecture whose epistemic and decision layers follow infrabayesian principles, providing formal decision-error guarantees.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Adoption occurs during initial model design choices. (Implicit in discussion of using InfraBayes to design agents)
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Purely theoretical so far; no published prototypes. (No empirical implementation mentioned)
nodes.node_rationale: Direct actionable step to mitigate the primary risk.

nodes.name: Stagnated adoption of promising alignment frameworks
aliases: slow uptake of new alignment theories
nodes.description: If researchers cannot understand new theories, the community may fail to adopt them, leaving safety improvements unrealised.
nodes.node_rationale: Post emphasises a ‘communication problem’ limiting use of InfraBayes. (Paragraphs on bouncing off write-ups)

nodes.name: Poor accessibility of existing infrabayesianism write-ups
aliases: high comprehension barrier of InfraBayes sequence
nodes.description: Current materials require advanced topology, measure theory and RL background; many researchers ‘bounce off’ after initial reading.
nodes.node_rationale: Root cause of stagnated adoption. (Main body paragraphs plus bullet-list of required maths)

nodes.name: Comprehensive and well-edited educational materials improve comprehension among researchers
nodes.description: Pedagogically sound material can bridge the gap between the advanced mathematics and the applied alignment community.
nodes.node_rationale: Implied assumption motivating the call for an editor. (Job description section)

nodes.name: Provide clear expository resources on infrabayesianism
nodes.description: Strategy: deliver rewritten posts, independent introductions, and structured exercises to convey the framework effectively.
nodes.node_rationale: Directly follows from the theoretical insight on educational impact. (Job description)

nodes.name: Develop textbook, exercise sheets, and rewrites with editorial support
nodes.description: Concrete mechanism: an editor works with authors to create a textbook, exercise sheets and improved blog posts, lowering the comprehension barrier.
nodes.node_rationale: Implementation details specified in the post under ‘probable activities’. (Job description)

nodes.name: Early-reader feedback indicating improved comprehension of infrabayesianism
nodes.description: Qualitative feedback (surveys, comments) from initial readers can validate whether the new materials actually enhance understanding.
nodes.node_rationale: Expected validation step for the communication intervention; lightly inferred. (Edge marked low confidence)

nodes.name: Hire math-savvy editor to create accessible infrabayesianism materials
nodes.description: Contract an individual with strong mathematical background and editorial skills to lead creation of textbooks, exercises and improved posts, thus reducing the learning barrier.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Action pertains to organisational/human-resource decisions beyond model development. (Call-to-action section)
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only a proposed job listing; no systematic evaluation yet. (Post is a solicitation)
nodes.node_rationale: Direct actionable step to unblock adoption pathway.
